New Records: Francisco Lindor hit a grand slam, breaking a 1-2 count and driving a 2-1 fastball into Philadelphia's bullpen for a 4-1 lead.
Edwin Díaz recorded his first postseason save by striking out Kyle Schwarber with two runners aboard to end the game.
The New York Mets reached the National League Championship Series for the first time in 24 years.
Key Match Events: Francisco Lindor's grand slam in the sixth inning was a turning point.
Edwin Díaz's game-ending strikeout with two runners aboard to secure the victory.
Philadelphia's error by third baseman Mark Vientos in the fourth inning allowed the Mets to score their only run.
Pre-Game Insights: The New York Mets were determined to overcome a challenging season and prove their resilience.
The Phillies, who had high expectations after their recent World Series appearances, struggled to capitalize on opportunities.
Post-Match Reflections: Francisco Lindor expressed his desire to win the World Series and his pride in the team's resilience.
Mets starter Jose Quintana allowed only two hits in five-plus innings, while David Peterson pitched 2 1/3 scoreless innings.
Philadelphia manager Rob Thomson acknowledged the team's performance and set sights on future success.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The sold-out crowd of 44,103 at Citi Field celebrated the Mets' first champagne-soaked clinching celebration in 16 seasons.
The game's significance for the Mets was highlighted by their long journey to the playoffs and their determination to overcome adversity.
